conversation.content: [confused] These payment records don't match what I submitted to the VA last month, and there are receipts here for textbooks that should have been covered by the Montgomery Bill. [pause] Margaret, what exactly have you been doing with these denied claims?

[quietly] Sometimes the system takes three, four months to process appeals, and these kids can't wait that long for their books or they'll fail their classes. [trailing off] I just thought I could help bridge the gap until...

[slowly] You've been paying for their materials yourself, haven't you? [very quietly] These withdrawals from your personal account, they match every single delayed benefit payment from the past two years.

[defensive] What was I supposed to do, tell Private Johnson's daughter she couldn't start nursing school because some bureaucrat lost her paperwork? [voice shaking] Tell the Martinez twins their father's service meant nothing when the computer glitched?
[softly] How much, Margaret?

[barely audible] Forty-seven thousand dollars, give or take, but most of it got reimbursed eventually when the benefits came through. [sighs] I kept thinking the next batch would process faster, that the new system upgrade would fix everything.

[gently] You refinanced your house last spring, didn't you? [pause] That wasn't for renovations like you told everyone in the break room, you were covering more students because the backlog got worse.

[trembling] My brother came back from Afghanistan with half his unit gone, couldn't even get his pharmacy benefits for six months. [quietly] These kids deserve better than what we're giving them, and if I can make it right somehow...

[regretful] I should have seen this sooner, should have noticed you staying late every night cross-referencing claims, making those calls to the families personally. [exhales] You've been carrying this whole broken system on your shoulders.

Someone has to care enough to actually fix things instead of just filing reports about why we can't help. [bitter] I've sat through too many meetings where we discuss metrics while real people suffer.

[firmly] Listen to me, we're going to get every penny back that you're owed, and I mean every receipt, every bank statement, everything. [warmly] There are emergency funds specifically for situations where the system fails, funds you should have been told about.
[hesitantly] Emergency funds?

[apologetic] The Warrior Relief Fund, the Veterans Community Living Centers grant program, at least six other sources that could have covered these expenses. [frustrated] They keep these programs so buried in red tape that even coordinators don't always know they exist.

[crying while speaking] I just wanted them to have the same chances my brother never got, to not lose a semester because someone misfiled a form. [sniffles] Every one of those kids reminds me of him trying to navigate this nightmare alone.

[empathetically] Your brother would be proud of what you've done, Margaret, but he wouldn't want you destroying yourself financially to fix a system that's been broken for decades. [pause] Let me help you fix this the right way.
The right way hasn't worked for two years of watching kids drop out because their housing allowance was delayed or their book stipend got lost in processing.

[passionately] Then we change how we do things, starting with documenting every single failure, every payment you made, every student who got helped because you stepped up. [firmly] We take this straight to the Inspector General's office if we have to.

[quietly] You could lose your position for going around the regional office like that, for making waves about their processing delays. [worried] They don't like coordinators who point out systemic failures.

[confidently] Some things are worth the risk, and making sure you get repaid while fixing this for future veterans is definitely one of them. [warmly] Besides, what are they going to do, fire both of us for actually helping veterans?

[relieved] You really think we can get the money back and change how this works? [hopefully] Because I've got three more students starting next month and their paperwork is already showing the same red flags as all the others.
